BE11:21am

It's all too fluid and chaotic for economists to keep up, of course, and we refuse to quote the daily guff and filler from spread betting types over here. Best I have to hand is Nomura.

BE11:21am

We think Dominic Raab's resignation is a big blow, without question. Esther McVey's is less so, but coming on the heels of Raab it adds to the narrative. What concerns us is how many ministers seeing this news will be pondering if it is better to get their resignations in now rather than wait. We have been here before with a minister or two resigning (i.e. David Davis and Boris Johnson after Chequers), but if several ministers go this becomes more difficult for Theresa May to hold her position. Huge numbers of questions from clients this morning show most are in scenario planning mode. Let's do some.

Kiwi-juice My friend at JPM said with the loss of passporting, 25% of the front moves, with choice given (Paris of Frankfurt). Housing bust likely. With the banks all rushing in the past 2 years to come up with 90-95% LTV mortgages...Lovely.
Excel Developer Might they resign one per hour, Leadsom, Mordaunt etc..
11:22 am
BE11:22am

1) Can May hold her job or will she resign? She is clearly tenacious – the fact she has survived this long is testament to that. However, a sufficient number of senior ministers resigning showing she has lost the Cabinet and she might feel her position is untenable. That opens up a leadership contest.
2) Will backbench MPs trigger a leadership contest? That is looking more likely post-Raab. If so, we have a confidence vote (most likely within a day or two). If Theresa May wins that then she is in a strong position as she can't be challenged for a year. This gives her the platform to force this deal through parliament by threats to both sides. In other words this outcome is not necessarily a bad one.

BE11:22am

3) Who wins a leadership contest? If she loses the confidence vote or has resigned then the question will be who is the next leader. This is a difficult question to answer as to who would actually put their hat in the ring and want to be PM right now? But there is a skew of risks here; given who might want to takeover at this juncture and who party membership might vote for (they get the final vote out of the last two candidates) the risk is a harder Brexiteer than May and consequently a higher chance of a harder Brexit being the end-result.

wayneJ Interesting - The UK's financial services sector contributed £71.4bn in tax last year, according to a report on behalf of the City of London.The total, which was the highest in the report's nine-year history, accounted for 11.5% of the UK's total tax receipts. (Source BBC - https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-38218662 )
Kiwi-juice @WayneJ: what about indirect taxes and indirect jobs? This is the real impact.
BE11:23am

The odds on Jeremy Hunt as next PM have come in from 9-1 to 7-1 since I started typing, incidentally: https://www.paddypower.com/politics

Excel Developer @waynej: yes!! worth reminding that.
11:23 am
BE11:23am

Not investment advice

mra1984 May be better than the stock market though!
BE11:24am

4) What are the tail risks here? A 'no-deal' Brexit cannot be ruled out – especially if there is a different leader of the party, but we still struggle to see a parliamentary majority for it. Not even close to one to be honest. However, a second referendum, while remaining a tail risk, is probably a more likely one than either a hard Brexit or a general election. Inadvertently or otherwise, Theresa May opened the door to it yesterday by saying the choice was this deal, no deal or no Brexit. That was a threat, I think, not an offer, but if there is no deal that can get through parliament you have to go back to the people one way or another and we suspect a majority of Conservative MPs would back a second referendum ahead of a general election if that was the choice.

J L @BE: I already placed my bets :-)
wayneJ Exactly - I think including indirect taxes (including eg legal / accounting / retailers etc) I reckon financial services is about 15-20% at least
BE11:24am

5) So what is going to happen? I would put it in this order of likelihood. I am not even going to try and put percentages on it yet – maybe when the dust has settled. But the order of likelihood I see is;
i) This deal somehow trudges on through parliament
ii) second referendum
iii) general election
iv) Hard Brexit

11:24 am
BE11:24am

6) What should the market do? Right now the market is trying to price in a level of uncertainty that is extremely high. That is bad for the pound and good for bonds. But it is very unclear what the end-state is. If you agree with our ordering above then from current levels the first option is quite bearish bonds, the second is very bearish, the third is bullish and the fourth is very bullish. If we are right in our ordering the risk to Gilt yields from here is still to the upside.

Lino Wishful thinking from Nomura re order of likelihoodUnless reverse order of likelihood for those scenarios
BE11:25am

7) How to trade this? Our portfolio of trades is suffering right now unsurprisingly. However, if we had to pick some trades to hold right now, at these levels, we still think they are the right ones for the view on the next 3m. If you look for a short-term hedge we see little value in the front-end. We are only pricing in 10bp of hikes for May – given it is unclear the MPC cuts even in Hard Brexit this is poor risk-reward, so hedges further out the curve would make more sense.

A. M. @wayneJ: A nation of stockbrokers, then?

Firstly, political divisions, which have already triggered high-profile Cabinet resignations, may also stoke a
(likely even more divisive) leadership challenge to Prime Minister Theresa May that would damage her
ability to coerce Conservative MPs to vote in favor of the WDA. Secondly, there may be a possible revolt in
the opposition Labour Party to become more pro-Remain. Finally, it is increasingly unlikely that the UK
Parliament will vote for the bill, if it indeed reaches that far.

BE11:32am

There are longer-term added uncertainties thrown up by the WDA publication, most notably the vaguerthan-
expected picture of any future trade relationship in a threadbare document released alongside.
However, this deliberate ambiguity is accentuated by a clearer provision to extend the transition period by
at least a year, as well as by the clearer hints that suggest the UK could remain in a de facto customs union
which, in turn, would limit its ability to negotiate separate trade deals. Already-damaged business
investment is also hardly likely to recover.
The WDA may not be dead on arrival, but it is both damaged and divisive. As such, May’s hitherto mantra
of ‘no deal is better than a bad deal’ has been turned on its head, but with a third option more and more
possible, i.e., an extension of negotiations beyond the March 2019 deadline.

It's been a year of weather-driven economics in the UK, with the Beast for the East in February
and March, then the heatwave in June and now a milder than usual Autumn. With all the noise, it
is hard to see what is going on. With wage growth pushing higher and inflation dropping fast -
particularly for retail goods - UK shoppers should be feeling a bit more bullish, despite the
weather. Yet the summer strength seems to have faded out and consumer confidence surveys also
suggest a somewhat subdued mood. In any case, with weaker activity and inflation projected by us
to be below the BoE's target next year - not to mention the political uncertainty which has of
course escalated in the last few days - we are comfortable with our view that the BoE will not raise
rates over our forecast period (to end-2020).

As expected the group has continued to make good progress in terms of operational and customer satisfaction improvements and is now fully sold for FY18. As such we see no need to change forecasts although the step up in part exchange usage since the half year end points to a tougher market. This means it may be more difficult to achieve the margin progression the market is expecting in FY19. While the shares are trading on a P/NAV of 1.3x, a c. 10% discount to the sector average, the operational returns lag the sector average by 25%. We see better value elsewhere in the sector. Hold.

BE11:46am

The sales rate for the year is in line with last year at 0.51x, and pricing is reportedly in line with expectations. Bovis states that it has seen some caution adopted by discretionary buyers, although we think this is only affecting a small number of sites that have higher price points. To maintain sales momentum, it has increased the use of partexchange, which is running at 15% of reservations – although the group is maintaining a disciplined approach with regard to balance sheet exposure and turning stock levels.
As previously alluded to, the group has increased land investment in order to maintain a 3.5-4.0 year landbank and in the period has acquired 1,988 plots, many of which have been secured from the strategic landbank. These investments are expected to generate a gross margin of at least 26% (EBIT margin c.21%) and ROCE of 25%. The Wellingborough JV is reportedly progressing and management remains confident of delivering £180m of cash release by end 2018.
● In our view, this update highlights how quickly the business has been turned around under the new management team. Operationally, the group is more controlled and this is partly evidenced by the improvement in margins and customer satisfaction. We think that Bovis can continue to show further margin growth (which underpins strong earnings growth) and will generate strong cash flow, supporting the dividend payment.
The shares are trading on 1.3x P/NTAV, 9x PE and a yield of 10%, which, in our view, fails to reflect the group’s improving profile and dividend yield.

BE11:50am

The Brexit negotiations are entering the endgame but the final outcome still remains highly uncertain. The technocrats have, as expected, hammered a draft text for the WA it is now up to the politicians to finalize the deal.
In our view, the risk to the deal succeeding or failing is now in the hands of UK MPs. Theresa May's slim parliamentary majority, only possible with the support of the DUP, may not hold up when the WA is first shown to MPs. We expect a period of political turbulence in the coming weeks and the collateral damage to the government could be sizeable.
However, we still think it is more likely than not that MPs will eventually ratify the WA as the alternative of a "no deal" exit will be a less enticing prospect.
At current levels sterling exchange rates trade neither in cliff-edge Brexit nor in soft Brexit territory. Hence, in order to confidently take positions in sterling again, more certainty is needed on the most likely outcome of the parliamentary vote on the deal.

H1 UK PIL and GLS volume growth looks in line with expectations set by the recent trading update. H1 revenue was some 2% shy of our expectations while operating profit (after transformation costs) was 3% below our expectations. The company has reconfirmed the £100m costs avoided target for year-end with £41m achieved in H1 leaving more to do in H2. The GLS has seen margin pressure as previously flagged but has also recognised a £68m impairment charge against goodwill and other assets as units are integrated. No change to overall guidance for the year.

BE11:57am

GLS remains under pressure — As was previously flagged, GLS margins remain under pressure. While revenue growth of +9% was solid, rising costs have seen the operating profit margin drop nearly 2% to 5.7% and the company has made a £68m impairment charge as it looks to integrate new units. Management is targeting a FY profit margin greater than 6% (Citi forecast 6.4%) so is expecting an improvement in H2.

BE12:04pm

3i has this morning reported its interim results for the six months to 30/9/18. The diluted NAV of 776p per share
(£7,548m) added to the dividend of 22p paid represents a TR of £728m, or 10% (Q1 5.1%, Q2 4.7%) from the
opening 724p. This was 1% below our JPMe of 784p, with no real market consensus according to the company
with few brokers producing an H1 NAV estimate, but still in our view a strong result in more difficult markets.
The gross investment return was £789m, or 12%. The big driver of performance here were unrealised gains from
the PE portfolio which contributed £417m, £342m of which was from earnings growth, with Action contributing
strongly (£271m), although it looks as though store growth will slow slightly as the necessary investment in
distribution centres takes place, reducing supply bottlenecks. This issues have been flagged before, and Action
itself was marked up by 15% over the first half (7% over the second quarter) on the strength of earnings growth
and is still contributing over 20% earnings growth; including Action, we estimate weighted average earnings
growth is 18%, and 13% ex, which remains impressive, in our view. Aggregate earnings multiples remain
modest, in our view, at an average of 11.1x EBITDA, broadly unchanged since March 18. With 8% of NAV
proforma net cash on the balance sheet 3i is in a strong position financially. However, with PE prices high it
won’t be rushing to spend this cash, focusing on bilateral transactions and bolt-ons, where there is less
competition. Our indicated live NAV is 780p which implies a premium of 8.9% at the current price of 849pps
(@8.30). This is very reasonable on historic grounds and given the underlying portfolio growth rate, defensive
nature of many of the assets, and a relatively low underlying valuation multiple, looks excellent value in our view. We remain Overweight.
